comments.commentBody:
It took me a bit longer than usual to complete this fine Monday puzzle. I didn't understand the significance of the circoedblettersbuntiobDeb enlightened me. Not seeing the theme didn't slow me down; it simply meant the theme was not helpful to my stomach love. Since that is common for me, I don't get too concerned about not seeing a theme.

Thanks for helping me get to sleep. It's been a busy, long and happy day at my house.

A belated Merry Christmas to those who celebrate same and a very Happy Chanukkah to those who celebrate same. Today is the day that inspired the phrase "many happy returns of the day" which is why I like to give legal tender to those who love me tender.

Oh, the puzzle. Yes. There was one today. It's square. Which reminds me, today is Monday. Mon is the stuff that's in the center of hamentashen. I believe it's made with poppy seeds which means you should not schedule any drug test during or for one week after Purim.

If none of this makes sense to you then you are probably normal.
It's "Mohn", HAL, so deck the HAHLs with Boughs of HahLahLahLy.
Arrrgh!  Now you have me doing pirate talk, Matey.
I should not post when I'm extremely tired. Even I don't know what stomach love was supposed to be. Goodnight all.

Always disheartening to see parents out with their young children, at the park, strolling on the trail, at the bakery or restaurant...and while the children are playing, the parents are heads-down, nose to the phone.  I wish they could know that in the blink of an eye, their children will be grown and gone.  All the while, they're missing it.

You are arguing present possession. You are not arguing for historical claim. The idea is by legitimizing historical possession, it allows for fresh and new claims based on history, and use that claim to invade and possess.

For example, the Russian Federation can say that given it is the successor nation to the USSR, and since the Baltic nations were all part of the USSR for half a century, it now has a legitimate claim to Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania. It then uses that claim to justify a march directly into the Baltic nations.

"We are waiting for the time when they finally democratize and recognize the right of the Taiwanese people to choose their own destiny."

I doubt this will happen in my lifetime without a major bloody revolt within the country or a major self-destructive schism within the CCP. The reaction to protests in Tiananmen today would be the same as it was 27 years ago.

Those in absolute power in a non-democracy do not voluntarily give up their power.

I'm glad the term "unification" was used here instead of the more common and misleading term "reunification". There is nothing to reunify because Taiwan and the People's Republic of China were never together.

The last time the same government oversaw the land area of Taiwan and the land area of China was in the 1600s!

The London problem was a more or less London issue.

This is an entirely separate scale. For instance, severe soil pollution is estimated to affect at least 100,000km2 in China. That's a bit under half the size of the UK as a whole.

The latest smog cloud is apparently the size of California. That's roughly twice the size of the UK as a whole.

Plus, there's the corruption issue.

Add to that the CCP will probably be lined up against the wall and shot sooner if the economy collapses/slows than they will if the air gets worse.

I suspect that was just because the school was closed.

It's getting pretty chilly there at the moment. High of six degrees.

If that seems strange logic, they really don't think things through:

1. Schools are closed. No getting around that.

2. Exams are scheduled. No getting around that.

Solution:
Have them outside. The schools are still closed and the exams still happen.

I did not like this puzzle at all
War too convoluted to be fun

Slightly off topic, but could it be that we are not measuring the right thing? We just had an electoral debacle partly because of too many un-employed, under-employed or under-paid voters in an economy that is "the best ever."

Job creation is never an objective of a capitalist--and today providing goods (and many services) can be done with very few jobs. When Facebook bought WhatsApp, it shelled out $22 billion for a company with only 55 staff -- a cool $400 million per employee. We can be sure that a very few of the 55 staff realized even $1 million, never mind $400 million.
Once the incremental labor costs to produce products is almost free, almost everyone needs to be providing a service--and our need for services is badly outstripped by those willing to provide them (except where protected by monopolies like doctors) so the wages stay low.
We need models that show us how to run an economy and provide enough income to citizens. Our current economy takes almost all of our productivity gains for the top .1 percent. The net is an economy with high inflation in goods like high end travel, or paintings by dead artists, but low inflation in more basic goods targeted to the 90%, and real hardship for an increasing percentage of our population.
Prof. Krugman's note points out that a simple model predicted some things not to do -- that were done anyway with the predicted bad results. We need to also see modeling of specific policies, like increasing the minimum wage. C
Strongly progressive taxation is the start of the solution to the concerns you raise. Helping the very numerous needy more generously would be an obvious second step.

“The first option for hostile forces infiltrating us is our education system,” the Chinese minister of education, Chen Baosheng, said in remarks published this month. “To wreck your future, first of all they wreck your schools.”

Truer words were never spoken. Simply consider the state of U.S. education -- although, admittedly, the G.O.P. had more to do with that wreckage than the C.C.P.

"seen inside the party as calculated moves in a grand plot"
the issue really isn't whether they are paranoid or crazy. what this tells us is that they are probably actually working with a grand plot against the west.
"In a time of universal deceit, telling the truth is a revolutionary act"

I put this article in the same category as "Death by China".  It's a broad brush that can't possibly cover  education, social and political policies in a country with 5x the population of the United States.  For one thing, the education is varied and sophisticated, with plenty of options for a broad education if desired by parents or brighter students.  Why would anyone think, for example, that China's leadership, would stop their best students from learning about the world in their formative years?  In my experience, students here are quite comfortable with being Chinese, and if they go to the US or Europe for education, most are going to enhance their education with the expectation of remaining Chinese.  We can acknowledge that some people are leaving for ideological reasons, but most people leaving China are doing so to protect their money. In other words, the system has more controls on its population than the United States, but this type of article fails to acknowledge that Chinese people have options
The article is about a propaganda video. Your response would seem to have little or nothing to do with the subject discussed.

Funny that westerners deny trying to destabilize china even though that is percisely what they had been doing all the time. Read the comments and articles in western media: all biased against china. And those western english teachers instilling anti government propaganda to their chinese students, need i to say more? Denying and commiting naughty things at the same time, how ironic.
I see the propaganda army is sparing no effort to criticize this article. Mr. Buckley's reportage must have struck a nerve in Zhongnanhai.
All articles published should allow readers to comment. To allow comments on only selectedv articals is a form of censorship
Thanks, you confirmed the basic premise of this report.

There was never any article about freedom in HK in the NYT or any western press when the British just appointed white governors to rule the place over a hundred years without ever asking the locals.

our readers here keep ranting on about China, their IQ, their oppression, their gullibility yet never realizing that all the time they are the brainwashed ones

How is it that you accuse the NYT and its readers of being brainwashed, when the article in question accurately describes what can only be understood as a propaganda effort (and a very blunt and crudely framed effort at that)?

@Bob
China is a business not a threat if you look at the list of countries with Trade Relations China's is double the number for the US and continuing expanding. Even those countries feeling imposed on by the China Sea issue do not see China as a threat, nor does the business sector in America, a view not shared by the working class in many cases. The Chinese Communist Party had become not only the darling of Wall Street but banker to the world. Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) to advance its own agenda. The AIIB is budgeted to spend about ten times as much in Asia as the Marshall Plan did in Europe, mostly to finance roads, railways, pipelines, electricity transmission, and other connectivity across Eurasia to smooth its own westward expansion.
China is trading infrastructure construction for the natural resources it desires. Few see that as threatening. Can American perception catch up with what is happening?

Christ Buckley’s articles always flow well beyond the headlines and deserve careful reading. “This conspiratorial worldview is more than bombast. It is a longstanding theme that has gained greater official credence under President Xi Jinping.” Is more that true and the Chinese minister of education, Chen Baosheng is the little man trying hard to please the boss.

The interesting question is what is driving Xi Jinping’s Maoist orthodoxy of the party above all, in all aspects of Chinese society, today. The CCP has always been about survival so that is too easy, but coming out of the transfer of power in 2012 to the Xi-Li new alignment were a bevy of Reforms that taken together are not far removed from what the students were demanding in 1989, an enhancement of legality and an opening of People input in the working of the system. That seems more and more waylaid as Xi becomes the Core Leader. Is the threat external or for Xi party centered? In this opaque system answers will come later?

"In the long run, a new structure with shorter chains would be built." This is true, but remember what Keynes said about the long run. In the meanwhile, China would have a range of retaliatory options for US  tariffs, far beyond raising their tariffs on American imports; for example, sharply increasing export duties on the many materials needed by American manufacturers to function, or, say, on semiconductors. At the far end of responses, the Chinese government could require that contracts entered into after a certain date be settled in RMB. I doubt there is any precedent for a trade war where one side has previously abandoned so much of its domestic production of goods and materials.
Can someone please share the numbers needed for good/excellent/genius?  Thank you.

Lisa --
7=Good, 13=Excellent, 19=Genius
Thank you Madeline. It's more fun to do with a goal in mind.

We won't realize how orderly things have been under Obama for 8 years until Trump starts mouthing off.  I keep saying it, I think it's true: we don't go longer than this before having another recession. But, it takes something unexpected to get one started--always. Can't imaging Trump doing something that can we?
Starts mouthing off?

I saw the 2008 crash coming a mile out.

https://fred.stlouisfed.org/graph/?g=cdAP

once the home equity borrowing bubble popped, hello debt deflationary collapse.

Not sure we will get a collapse this decade, recessions dont actually come out of nowhere.

Since the Arizona Republic publishes the NYT crossword a week late, I wonder if adding comments 7 days later even makes sense. Nevertheless, while the cluing symmetry was amazing, the boring & "really-stretching-it" fill made me yawn. RUMOR and INTER should have been clued differently- a rumor is dirt that's already been spread, inter is to spread dirt, past participle doesn't work here. Also, LIKE Norton software should be descriptive ANTIVIRAL or clue should be changed to more objective "target of Norton software". Don't get 67A DATE as "time in ads", can someone explain? Didn't like plural ALTARS & singular STABLE for "where to find grooms", non-consistent cluing. Hated REDAN, RADICLE, DETAG, REHOIST, TIPI and DAZER. Thanks for listening & Happy Hannukwanzmas to all.
